pros:
1) This may be surprising but I'm having adequate WLB - Bosses are flexible, colleagues are supportive - End of the day, it's an output driven company - Work smart and deliver results, you can plan how your schedule goes.

2) Culture is great, there are team bonding budgets for team planned activities, social activity clubs for people to participate outside of work (running club / badminton club etc)

3) It's always about looking to be better, faster and of higher quality - The company is relentless in its pursuit of excellence which is why they have grown to what they are today

4) I was blessed with great team managers, through them I felt empowered and they had often pushed me to do better - Again, this is all in the mindset, do you perceive feedback as constructive or criticism?

5) Compensation is competitive but when is money ever enough?
cons:
1) Systems are not the best, unintuitive and often fragmented - You will need to be versatile in finding alternative ways to track your own work processes and deliverables

2) Ambiguity is really for breakfast, lunch and dinner - If you enjoy solving problems as they come and not having a dull day, this will be great

3) Structure is more business group driven as opposed to a regional format, might take some adjusting of mindsets to get used to the matrixed environment

4) Market share in some business groups may not be great but that presents opportunities to make things happen

5) Pros mentioned above might vary from team to team, it still largely depends on the team's leadership and style - so please do your own due diligence during the interview process

review_title: The Chinese Tech Company that cares for it's employees. Worth Recommending!
pros:
- great company values and indeed they practiced it in Singapore- "Value for Users, Tech for Good"
- as I came from another fast-growing Chinese Tech Company, I can say that not all Chinese tech companies are the same category. Tencent Singapore definitely demonstrated their values and truly care for it's employees, at least for my team
- Though my manager is based at Shenzhen HQ, there's no challenge in communicating across the region and my manager understand the importance of Work Life Balance in Singapore
- 996 is NOT valid in Singapore office
- as a recruiter, I get to work on many pioneer roles and for the exciting fast growing business, which is EXCITING!
- almost everyone is very friendly and approachable so far
- overall great attractive remuneration
cons:
- too bad we can't really work in office and meet with other colleagues due to covid period
- doesn't have 'own office' like Google yet, but the shared office for now is very comfortable too 
- the tech system internally is not the best and many areas for improvements but not a major concern
- the overall perks and benefits can continue to improve

review_title: Review from a backend software engineer
job_title: Senior Backend Software Engineer in Shenzhen, Guangdong
pros: Great benefit among all Chinese Internet giants, fancy building, nice colleagues and culture.
cons:
1. Bad work life balance. For product managers, you have to deal with "product requirements from boss" at off-duty-time. And engineers have to spend a lot of time on those whims even in the deep night.
2. Lack of high-level design on the whole company's tech-infrastructure, so that a lot of engineers are exhausting on re-inventing wheels and on-call for online service fault.
3. Some of the senior/middle managers (VP/GM) are not professional enough. They sometimes focus on too much on detailed problems which shall be solved by engineers or product managers themselves.
4. Top-level company and products, second-level salaries.

review_title: Foreign Staff are well taken care of
job_title: Game Operations Specialist in Shenzhen, Guangdong
pros:
Towards the end of 2021, I had a couple of offers from the gaming companies I interviewed with. I was sceptical about whether to choose Tencent or a foreign company based in China. After hearing rave reviews, I decided to join Tencent, and I don't regret it a bit. 

- Excellent welfare
- Friendly colleagues 
- Flex work hours 
- Productive environment 
- Professional HR staff
- Free coffee (This might be irrelevant for many, but as a coffee lover who spends a fortune every month on good coffee beans, it's a perk for me)
cons:
- The HR process takes time, which is understandable given the massive number of onboarding personnel. So this might test your patience. 
- The resources for foreign employees are not as abundant as for the local staff. So we have to accept it and move on.

job_title: Front End Developer in Shenzhen, Guangdong
pros:
- Salary is good.
- It's a big company.
cons:
- Rent is high there.
- Work time is long.

pros:
Hours: It's like at university. Most of your time is free period where you can control your work hours. No one expects you to be on the dot at 9am if there's no meeting. As long as you communicate with your team on project needs, your hours are yours to dictate. If anyone complains about OT, it's usually voluntary because they want to put more effort into their project.

Culture: Very open-minded colleagues. They're usually bilingual or multilingual, so they understand various perspectives from different cultures. My manager and colleagues frequently ask for my opinion on various things, regardless of seniority. I can speak my mind, as long as I say it in a way that's appropriate for the given audience (i.e. colleague my level vs hiring manager). Trust me, it's fun to hear 2 languages going on throughout a single meeting. It makes you feel like you're truly working for an MNC. Also, the people are honest and have a high sense of integrity. They're transparent about their intentions, want to protect their colleagues like family, and help them grow career-wise.

Management: They try to put me on challenging projects that highlight my strengths and don't rely too much on my weaknesses.

Compensation: Generous + the red packet culture
cons: If you're working directly with the HQ, and have never worked for a Chinese company before, there may be the normal culture shock and language barrier. If you work closely with the HQ, then you need to understand that high-context communication style, as opposed to direct communication style in American companies.

pros:
1. Good salary and working environment. 
2. Good employer reputation in China.
3. Has a great trainee program for junior game designers.
cons:
1. Bad WLB. Need to work overtime almost every day.

2. Forced ranking system to punish (bonus cuts or even dismission) employees who ranked low. No matter employees' actual performance, about 10-20% of them need to be marked as "need to improve" or "unsatisfied" forcibly based on the system. If everyone in your team works hard, that will be a tragedy.

3. Limited experience in game design know-how and methodology. It is ok in the past, but crucial and lethal when Tencent wants to produce AAA titles to expand the global market.

4. Impatient managers. They expect developers to effectively produce and iterate content with superior quality (ideally to finish a AAA quality game in a year) but leave limited time. If the test data of your game is non-ideal, they will cut your project unhesitatingly.

5. Unfriendly for international employees.

review_title: Join the company only if you want to not accomplish anything
pros: Benefits are good, food every Wednesday, things tech companies normally do
cons:
Favoritism - There is definitely favoritism, if they like you, you can do whatever you want.

Managers - Those that are leads from China, give you no room to grow and everything needs to go through them for approval prior.  Takes forever to make a decision.  Those managers are often seen as immune from any type of disciplinary issues as often complaints are "investigated" but nothing is done to change.  They steal all of your work and give no credit to you and either take the credit themselves or give that credit to those that are around them.

Company uses a employee rating system, and though it isn't a bad system, the managers will give a bad rating to anyone they don't like, and won't offer an explanation of that bad rating.

All in all, I will say, if you want to be nothing, and do nothing, appear to be working and 
 just never shine as a employee, I think its the job for you.  You will go through life just collecting a check and whittling away until they get rid of you.

But what am I saying, most employees will read this and want to take a chance anyways.

review_title: Not a good employer in the US
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Flexibility, great benefits, competitive pay and people in the US
cons:
China HQ is out of touch with reality.  They want people in the US to do things that are not legal and after carefully explaining the issues, HQ management says you are not cooperative and penalizes you. 

There is zero growth opportunity in the US office; it's far too small and treated like a step-child.

They want to expand in the West but won't commit like they are too afraid to fail.  They hire very bright leaders in the US (because they are the experts on the US markets and products) to build up products/platforms for the West but then won't let them implement their plans - China says they know better and makes them do things their way in the end.  Additionally, they won't commit to hiring a full western team and require the US managers to utilize resources in China.

review_title: Tencent is better than most Chinese IT/gaming companies
pros: Good benefit, lots of perks, huge amount of year end bonus if your game project makes lot of money. Many colleagues are elites in the industry, each has her/his unique story, you can learn a lot from them. Even if you leave Tencent, it's easier to get a new job elsewhere because Tencent's reputation.
cons: Lots of crunch time, there is no checks and balances between project management side and creative side (the product owners/producers has power over PMs, PMs report to producers, that's not really ideal.  , scope vs capacity are not carefully planned. If project leaders want to keep deadline, most of times they just abruptly puts people on OT without considering some mitigation plans. can't blame them because they too got pressure from more senior level.

job_title: Project Manager in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Very positive work environment with a great team, a lot of passion for good games. Blooming company for business development professionals. Great benefits, nice salary, very supportive upper management.
cons:
At this point, Tencent America is not a production company. It doesn't produce games. It is not an disadvantage for the company really, since it is their strategy and it's good for the company's overall growth both in the US and in China. But it's probably not a good choice if you're looking for a production orientated jobs. 

Also, the company works with China headquarters as well as partners all over Europe, the working hour might get a bit crazy. I don't mind it, but if you have family, kids to take care of, might want to take that into consideration.

review_title: A good internet company to work for in China
pros: The HR department is amazing, they have all sorts of small perks for employees including gifts during different holidays, all sorts of extra curriculum activities that you can join, health advises, etc.  The Company overall promotes creative and self opinion, their top senior management are really approachable.  The value of the Company are well promoted.  It is one of the best online game companies in China open minded and caring for employees.  This is very rare in a Company.
cons:
Although the Company values self-opinion and creativity, on the execution level, there are some really mean bully and close minded mid-level management that will ignore subordinates and micromanage the team.  
Given that the Company is already really large, it is hard to feel a person's work really matters.

review_title: Pretty good place to work, but difficult if you don't speak mandarin
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
Really excellent benefits
Most employees are kind and sensible people
Nice office in a good part of town
Good salaries
High quality random swag gifts
Opportunities to travel abroad
cons:
Working in the US office is extremely difficult if you don't speak Mandarin. You may feel socially excluded and depending on your department, you may be cut off from certain kinds of career advancement opportunities
Some departments in the US office have, in the past, been grievously misused by management in China. Despite its good investments in videogames and tech, Tencent in general does not have a strong strategy for actually doing business in the west and will often start and stop projects in the US at the drop of the hat. This can be a major career blocker for the western employees assigned to those projects
Some of the management in China seems fundamentally unsuited to managing employees in the US. This includes American-born management working in China.
Some employees in China tend to ignore work done or recommendations given by employees in the US, particularly if those US employees do not speak Mandarin
Once you get off the high of getting a cool trip to a foreign country, you may become exhausted by demands to travel to China over and over again, particularly at times of the year which are sensitive to US employees but not Chinese employees. For example, they may ask you over and over again to spend several weeks in China at the end of December
While US HR obeys US labor laws, the departments in China do not seem to have many of the protections we have and you  may find yourself in some awkward situations if you go over there and visit. However the biggest harm you are likely to experience is to your sense of self-respect at being associated with a company that does this kind of shit-- in general, I was treated very respectfully
Throughout Tencent, disruptive reorganizations are common and it is likely that your job or task will change frequently, often before you are able to make any big successes for yourself. Because this is ubiquitous in the company however it is not exactly a career blocker

pros: The most important reason is PM driven's company, it focus on the product design, think about where are your customers, and what's mission in our product. It would make you look for the essential idea.
cons: leadership: As a leader of PM team, I feel more responsible of strategy of product. The company improves the team has the own decision for the perspective of product as a startup company.
